awd_titl_txt: CAREER: CDS&E: Developing Reaction-Diffusion Models of Non-Equilibrium Virion Assembly and Budding
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Margaret E. Johnson of Johns Hopkins University is supported by an award from the Chemistry of Life Processes and Chemical Theory, Models, and Computational Methods programs in the Division of Chemistry to develop and apply novel theoretical and computer simulation methods for studying virion formation, budding, and membrane remodeling leading to virion release at the cell membrane. Virions are the infective virus particles, and consist of viral DNA or RNA enclosed by a protein shell.  Dr. Johnson is investigating how retroviral Gag (Group-specific Antigen) proteins perpetuate viral infection by assembling new virions on the membranes of infected cells. A molecular understanding of this critical step in the lifecycle of infectious virions can help identify targets for therapeutic intervention against viral infection.  The new reaction-diffusion modeling software being developed by Dr. Johnson for this project provides the missing link coupling short molecular length-scales (chemistry) with the slow time-scales of cellular self-assembly and membrane budding (membrane mechanics).  The models are being tested and iteratively refined against live cell experiments. The modeling software, graphical user interface, and rule-based model definition framework are being disseminated as open-source software and made compatible with other widely-used biophysical modeling tools, providing a transformative new approach for understanding and controlling essential cellular processes, including those involved in cell division or in viral infections. The research is closely integrated with an educational outreach program designed to improve diversity and therefore outcomes in STEM fields by teaching computer programming to Baltimore City Elementary School students. The after-school module introduces students to the power of computers in solving outstanding problems in biology and chemistry, with the goal of promoting and encouraging future careers in STEM.

The goal of this project is to develop a rate-based computational model of virion formation in the cell, to determine the mechanisms of recruitment and assembly of the central retroviral Gag protein on the membrane. While the components of the final virion are known, pathways of assembly are poorly understood because the dynamics is sensitive to protein production, kinetics, membrane composition, and cellular co-factors. In this project, computer simulations of the virion components are directly compared with live-cell experiments to determine and describe the time- and space- and structure-dependent mechanisms of Gag lattice assembly in vivo, and provide a mechanism for iterative model refinement. The computational approach is made possible by the implementation of new reaction-diffusion methods for non-equilibrium assembly and membrane remodeling. The deepened understanding of virion formation and mechanistic pathways has application to predictive control over successful viral exit from infected cells, and informing strategies for therapeutic intervention. This research is contributing to the ability of the broader scientific community to study mechanisms of non-equilibrium dynamics of the cell at unprecedented resolution through public access to the powerful new methods and software being developed for the project.  The research is integrated with an educational outreach program to actively promote and encourage students from diverse backgrounds in Baltimore city to consider futures in STEM by teaching them computer programming and its applications in chemistry and biology. By focusing on elementary school students, this research program will help to foster, early on, interest in STEM fields, using Professor Johnson's computational research program as a motivation and application.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In this project, "Developing Reaction-Diffusion Models of Non-Equilibrium Virion Assembly and Budding", we developed and published open-source software that allows the larger scientific community to simulate macromolecular self-assembly with spatial and temporal resolution that can be directly compared with experiment. This general-purpose software has been applied to study a variety of nonequilibrium self-assembly processes, including key steps in clathrin-mediated endocytosis and viral assembly and maturation.

By developing a model of the HIV immature Gag lattice based on structures determined from cryo electron tomography experiments, we addressed two key outstanding questions about the assembly and maturation of the HIV virion in infected cells. First, we showed how the kinetics of the immature lattice assembly is controlled by co-factor binding to ensure productive assembly and avoid kinetic trapping. We combined theory, simulation, and experimental measurements to determine bounds on the stability and binding rates of the Gag-Gag and co-factor interactions that stabilize lattice assembly.  Second, we addressed an outstanding question on the process of maturation in retroviruses that is essential to their infectivity: how does a pair of protease domains find one another to activate maturation when they are seemingly 'locked in' to the assembled lattice and represent only 5% of total lattice proteins? We showed through our model along with validation against several experimental observables that the incomplete structure of the immature lattice allows sufficient dynamics to trigger dimerization events within minutes. Inhibitors designed to suppress maturation target the lattice we modeled, and specifically modify its stability; our work predicts how stabilization quantitatively shifts lattice remodeling and assembly. More broadly, the biophysics of most viruses requires assembling proteins into ordered lattices that must interact with biological membranes, and our study quantitatively predicts how lattice stability can be tuned for assembly vs remodeling dynamics.   

In this project we also produced open-source software for continuum models of membrane mechanics that we validated against experimental measurements of protein binding and recruitment to curved membranes. This model can be applied to predict how the lipid composition and topology of biological membranes influences protein recruitment and remodeling of membranes during viral budding and more generally throughout cell biology. Overall this project resulted in 6 research publications with the lead PI as the corresponding author.

We partnered with an outreach program for STEM achievement in Baltimore Elementary Schools (SABES) run in collaboration with Johns Hopkins University and the Village Learning Place in Baltimore MD. We developed a new curriculum to be used in after school programs to inspire students to learn and get excited about computer programming and its applications in chemistry and biology.  Importantly, this includes a website (https://computersinscience.wordpress.com/) that supports this program, acts as a central location for our curriculum, and a resource that we use to provide access to scientific animations, as well as simulations. Students learned programming through the MIT Scratch interface and several examples of their work are on this class website https://scratch.mit.edu/users/sabes2019/ . We also worked with the students throughout their community-driven projects to identify and come up with solutions within their community, helping them build portable shelters for homeless persons and air filters to reduce pollution.


Last Modified: 09/13/2023
Modified by: Margaret E Johnson

Images (1 of )
  • Examples of Immature Gag lattices that were stochastically assembled from monomeric building blocks. Orange hexamers have favorable contacts while red regions contain defects in the lattice. Coverage and distribution of defects on the spherical membrane is in close agreement with cryoET experiments.
    Sikao Guo
    Copyrighted
    Margaret E Johnson
    Immature Gag lattices
  • With our model, we can track the dynamics of the Gag lattice as monomers and small oligomers detach from the incomplete edge and rebind to form protease dimers.
    Sikao Guo
    Copyrighted
    Margaret E Johnson
    Gag lattice dynamics
  • We derived a timescale to slowly activate Gag monomers into their assembly competent form and thus robustly and compactly form complete Gag lattices for a range of lattice stabilities and kinetics. Red is the total Gag monomers in time, gray are the assembly sizes.
    Yian Qian
    Copyrighted
    Margaret E Johnson
    Gag assembly kinetics
  • With the continuum membrane model we implemented, we can measure how binding of proteins to surface regions of distinct curvature, as shown in the red-blood cell shaped membrane, quantitatively alters the binding energy.
    Yiben Fu
    Copyrighted
    Margaret E Johnson
    Binding energy by curvature
  • We partnered with SABES at Johns Hopkins and the Village Learning place to develop a computer programming curriculum for after-school science programs in Baltimore Elementary Schools. Students learned to code animations and interactive videos using the MIT Scratch icon-based language.
    Margaret Johnson
    Copyrighted
    Margaret E Johnson
    SABES students
por.por_txt_cntn:
In this project, "Developing Reaction-Diffusion Models of Non-Equilibrium Virion Assembly and Budding", we developed and published open-source software that allows the larger scientific community to simulate macromolecular self-assembly with spatial and temporal resolution that can be directly compared with experiment. Second, we addressed an outstanding question on the process of maturation in retroviruses that is essential to their infectivity: how does a pair of protease domains find one another to activate maturation when they are seemingly 'locked in' to the assembled lattice and represent only 5% of total lattice proteins? This model can be applied to predict how the lipid composition and topology of biological membranes influences protein recruitment and remodeling of membranes during viral budding and more generally throughout cell biology. Overall this project resulted in 6 research publications with the lead PI as the corresponding author.

We partnered with an outreach program for STEM achievement in Baltimore Elementary Schools (SABES) run in collaboration with Johns Hopkins University and the Village Learning Place in Baltimore MD. We developed a new curriculum to be used in after school programs to inspire students to learn and get excited about computer programming and its applications in chemistry and biology. Students learned programming through the MIT Scratch interface and several examples of their work are on this class website https://scratch.mit.edu/users/sabes2019/ . We also worked with the students throughout their community-driven projects to identify and come up with solutions within their community, helping them build portable shelters for homeless persons and air filters to reduce pollution.
